articles.headline: Volkswagen Will Invest Up to $5 Billion in Rivian
articles.snippet: VW and Rivian, a maker of electric trucks that has struggled to increase sales and break even, will work together on software and other technologies.
articles.abstract: VW and Rivian, a maker of electric trucks that has struggled to increase sales and break even, will work together on software and other technologies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Volkswagen, the German automaker, said on Tuesday that it would invest up to $5 billion in Rivian, a maker of electric trucks that has struggled to turn a profit, and that the companies would cooperate on software for electric vehicles.

articles.headline: Anti-Tax Riots Rock Kenya, as President Vows Crackdown on ‘Treasonous’ Protesters
articles.snippet: At least five people were killed in clashes with the police that erupted after lawmakers approved tax increases that critics said would drive up the cost of living for millions.
articles.abstract: At least five people were killed in clashes with the police that erupted after lawmakers approved tax increases that critics said would drive up the cost of living for millions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Thousands of demonstrators flooded the streets of Kenya’s capital, Nairobi, and some broke into Parliament and briefly set fire to the entrance on Tuesday, after lawmakers approved tax increases that critics said would drive up the cost of living for millions.
articles.byline: By Abdi Latif Dahir and Declan Walsh

articles.headline: For American Brands Worried About China, Is India the Future?
articles.snippet: As multinational retailers diminish their dependence on Chinese factories, some are shifting production to India.
articles.abstract: As multinational retailers diminish their dependence on Chinese factories, some are shifting production to India.
articles.lead_paragraph: Melissa & Doug had a situation. For decades, the American toy brand had leaned heavily on factories in China to make its products — wooden puzzles, stuffed animals, play mats. Suddenly, that course looked risky.

articles.headline: When the Terms of Service Change to Make Way for A.I. Training
articles.snippet: Tech companies have been making subtle and not-so-subtle changes to their rules for better access to data for building A.I. We took a look at some of them.
articles.abstract: Tech companies have been making subtle and not-so-subtle changes to their rules for better access to data for building A.I. We took a look at some of them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last July, Google made an eight-word change to its privacy policy that represented a significant step in its race to build the next generation of artificial intelligence.

articles.headline: Joe Biden: The Old-School Politician in a New-School Era
articles.snippet: After more than half a century in Washington, President Biden has learned to make deals and work across the aisle. But that instinct is rarely rewarded in today’s political climate.
articles.abstract: After more than half a century in Washington, President Biden has learned to make deals and work across the aisle. But that instinct is rarely rewarded in today’s political climate.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow live updates on the 2024 presidential debate here.

articles.headline: Kenyan President Rejects Bill That Led to Deadly Protests
articles.snippet: A day after at least 23 people were killed in demonstrations against a tax increase, President William Ruto withdrew the law that he said was necessary to avoid defaulting on the country’s debt.
articles.abstract: A day after at least 23 people were killed in demonstrations against a tax increase, President William Ruto withdrew the law that he said was necessary to avoid defaulting on the country’s debt.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a sudden reversal, President William Ruto of Kenya announced on Wednesday that he would not sign a finance bill that he had long said would stabilize the country’s economy — a response to devastating protests a day earlier that left nearly two dozen people dead.

articles.headline: Supreme Court Rejects Challenge to Biden Administration’s Contacts With Social Media Companies
articles.snippet: The case, one of several this term on how the First Amendment applies to technology platforms, was dismissed on the ground that the plaintiffs lacked standing to sue.
articles.abstract: The case, one of several this term on how the First Amendment applies to technology platforms, was dismissed on the ground that the plaintiffs lacked standing to sue.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court handed the Biden administration a major practical victory on Wednesday, rejecting a Republican challenge that sought to prevent the government from contacting social media platforms to combat what it said was misinformation.
